docs.snippet: ANDERSON--Robert. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of former Guild President Robert Woodruff Anderson, who died at the age of 91 on February 9, 2009. An acclaimed playwright, novelist and screenwriter, his credits include the Broadw...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANDERSON--Robert. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of former Guild President Robert Woodruff Anderson, who died at the age of 91 on February 9, 2009. An acclaimed playwright, novelist and screenwriter, his credits include the Broadway play "Tea and Sympathy" (1953), which he adapted for the screen in 1956, and his Oscar-nominated screenplays for "The Nun's Story" (1959) and "I Never Sang for My Father" (1970), which he adapted from his play. Mr. Anderson joined the Dramatists Guild in 1941 and was elected to the Dramatists Guild governing council in 1965, serving as DG Council President from 1971 to 1973. He also served on the Board of The Dramatists Guild Fund from 1962 to 1993. His understanding of the playwright's plight in America led to his slyly knowing and oft-quoted observation: "The theater is a place where you can make a killing, but you can't make a living." A gentleman of great dignity, elegance and compassion, Mr. Anderson will be missed. Our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. John Weidman, President Dramatists Guild of America

docs.snippet: 8 P.M. (TCM) 31 DAYS OF OSCAR: PRINCIPLES OF ANIMAL BEHAVIOR  Turner Classic Movies presents films about our furry friends, starting with Carroll Ballard's ''Never Cry Wolf'' (1983), about a government researcher (Charles Martin Smith) stranded in...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) 31 DAYS OF OSCAR: PRINCIPLES OF ANIMAL BEHAVIOR Turner Classic Movies presents films about our furry friends, starting with Carroll Ballard's ''Never Cry Wolf'' (1983), about a government researcher (Charles Martin Smith) stranded in Canada, and followed by ''Lassie Come Home'' (1943), with Roddy McDowall, at 10; ''National Velvet'' (1944), with Elizabeth Taylor (above, with Mickey Rooney), at 11:45; ''The Jungle Book'' (1942), starring Sabu, at 2 a.m.; and ''The Day of the Dolphin'' (1973), with George C. Scott, at 3:45 a.m. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Jessica Simpson performs. Clive Owen promotes his latest film, ''The International,'' while his co-star Naomi Watts appears on ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 on ABC. Annie Lennox is that show's musical guest.

docs.snippet: Film | "The Reader," about an illiterate death camp guard, joins a disturbing mini-trend in films exculpating Germans in the Holocaust, the author of "Explaining Hitler" writes ("Valkyrie" is another). "You had to be deaf, dumb, and blind, not mer...
docs.lead_paragraph: Film | "The Reader," about an illiterate death camp guard, joins a disturbing mini-trend in films exculpating Germans in the Holocaust, the author of "Explaining Hitler" writes ("Valkyrie" is another). "You had to be deaf, dumb, and blind, not merely illiterate, to miss what Kate Winslet's character seems to have missed (while serving as a guard at Auschwitz!). You'd have to be exceedingly stupid. As dumb as the Oscar voters who nominated 'The Reader' because it was a 'Holocaust film.' " [Slate]
docs.abstract: Film | "The Reader," about an illiterate death camp guard, joins a disturbing mini-trend in films exculpating Germans in the Holocaust, the author of "Explaining Hitler" writes ("Valkyrie" is another). "You had to be deaf, dumb, and blind, not merely illiterate, to miss what Kate Winslet's character seems to have missed (while serving as a guard at Auschwitz!)."[Slate]

docs.snippet: Noah Forrest, writing at Movie City News, suggests that almost any year and any movie should result in an Oscar for Kate Winslet, but he throws a flag on her performance in "The Reader."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Noah Forrest, writing at Movie City News, suggests that almost any year and any movie should result in an Oscar for Kate Winslet, but he throws a flag on her performance in "The Reader." Mr. Forrest suggests that just because Ms. Winslet has been robbed of four nominations, two wins (he thinks she should have won for "Little Children" and "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind") , and Lord knows what else, is no reason to use "The Reader" as an occasion for a make-good. He cites the Academy's history of giving the right actor the award for the wrong movie (Jack Lemmon and "Save the Tiger," for example).
docs.abstract: Noah Forrest, writing at Movie City News, suggests that almost any year and any movie should result in an Oscar for Kate Winslet, but he throws a flag on her performance in "The Reader."

headline.main: Yes, Kate. Many Times Over. But Not for 'The Reader'

docs.snippet: If the movies executives are looking for a way forward, maybe they should make movies shorter, a lot shorter, and then run them together on multiple bills....
docs.lead_paragraph: If the movies executives are looking for a way forward, maybe they should make movies shorter, a lot shorter, and then run them together on multiple bills. According to Vulture, Oscar-nominated shorts currently screening at the IFC Center in New York broke the venue's single-screen record this weekend, earning $24,006.
docs.abstract: If the movies executives are looking for a way forward, maybe they should make movies shorter, a lot shorter, and then run them together on multiple bills.

docs.snippet: The Bagger was out in Times Square last night, making video and asking people about the Oscars. And you know what, most people acted like he was asking whether they were wearing boxers or briefs....
